Lita, es una mujer muy jovial, alegre y optimista que se inicio  gracias a la ayuda de sus amigas  quienes fueron sus primeras clientas, viendo que si le hacían los pedidos es que se animó a hacerlo ahora cuenta con buena clientela,  ella vende  aprovecha las ofertas para hacerse de sus productos y venderlos  precio de catálogo y poder ganar mas.En la actualidad tiene una clientela ya fidelizada, ella vende al contado y al crédito con pagos de manera diaria, semanal quincenal o mensual.Con este préstamo de S/ 800.00, comprará productos de belleza como colonias, esmaltes, bijuoteria  como aretes, collares y anillos, así como perfumes para varón que salen en ofertas, quiere tener surtido su negocio y dar una buena  atención a sus clientes y encuentren lo que necesiten. Lita, sueña con crecer en este negocio y llegar a ser una vendedora estrella para ganar buenos premios. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a implementar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren desarrollarse en lo personal y en el negocio.

loans.use: Comprará productos de catalogo, para aumentar su stock.

loans.name: Maria Cruz

texts.es: La señora Maria Cruz, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de Guadalupe II”, vive en el Jr. Belén Nº 650, Distrito de Bagua Grande, Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento de Amazonas. Es conviviente, tiene 45 años tiene 3 hijos, 01 varón y 02 mujeres,  todos aun en etapa escolarSu espíritu emprendedor y la necesidad de ayudar en el ingreso económico del hogar le motivo a iniciarse en el negocio y no vio la mejor manera de hacerlo con el primer préstamo que le otorgaron de S/. 300.00,  con esto ella compró lo que mas le pedían los vecinos quienes fueron sus primeros clientes, hoy continua con la misma actividad, ella vende de manera ambulatoria en la ciudad y los fines de semana sale a los pueblos mas cercanos  para incrementar sus ventas. Con este préstamo de S/. 1000.00, comprará polos, para damas caballeros y niños, blusas, pantalones de hombre y mujer, pijamas, ropa de bebe, sabanas y colchas que son los que mas salida tienen entre su clientela; le gusta contar con stock de mercadería para poder satisfacer las exigencias de  sus clientes.Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, pese que es un trabajo que le demanda bastante tiempo ,  cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida como son el de tener su propia casa.
texts.en:
Señora Maria Cruz belongs to the community bank “Virgen de Guadalupe II” (Virgin of Guadalupe II). She lives in Jr. Belén Nº 650, Bagua Grande District, Utcubamba Province, Department of Amazonas. She is 45 years old and lives with three children, one boy and two girls, all of whom are still in grade school. Her enterprising spirit and the necessity of helping with household income motivated her to go into business, though she didn’t see the best way of doing so.

With the first loan granted to her of 300 soles she purchased what the neighbors who were her first customers asked for the most. Today, she continues with the same activity. She sells in an itinerant manner in the city, and on weekends she goes to nearby towns in order to increase her sales.

With this loan of 1000 soles she will buy polo shirts for women, men and children; blouses; men’s and women’s pants; pajamas; baby clothes; sheets and comforters that are most in demand among her customers. She likes to have an inventory of merchandise in order to be able to satisfy the requirements of her customers. She feels very satisfied with her work. Though it demands a lot of time, she believes that it is worth the sacrifice in order to achieve her dreams and goals that she has planned for her life, such as having her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy clothes in order to increase her inventory

loans.name: Miguelina

texts.es: La señora Miguelina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de Guadalupe II”, Distrito de Bagua Grande, Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento de Amazonas. Es conviviente, tiene 39 años tiene 3 hijos, 02 varones y 01 mujer,  todos aun en etapa escolar.  Miguelina, es una mujer muy jovial, alegre y optimista que se inicio vendiendo para otra persona hasta conseguir clientes y animarse a vender para ella, viendo que si le hacían los pedidos y fue cunado una amiga le animó a hacerlo, tal es así que ahora ella vende para ella y aprovecha las ofertas para hacerse de sus productos y venderlos  precio de catálogo y poder ganar mas.En la actualidad tiene una clientela ya fidelizada, ella vende al contado y al crédito con pagos de manera diaria, semanal quincenal o mensual.Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, comprará productos de belleza como colonias, esmaltes, bijuoteria  como aretes, collares y anillos, así como perfumes para varón que salen en ofertas y un exhibidor para poder dar a conocer y cuidar sus productos, quiere tener surtido su negocio y dar una buena  atención a sus clientes y encuentren lo que necesiten. Miguelina, sueña con crecer en este negocio y llegar a ser una vendedora estrella para ganar buenos premios. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a implementar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren desarrollarse en lo personal y en el negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Miguelina belongs to the community bank Virgin of Guadalupe II in the District of Bagua Grande, Province of Utcubamba, Department of Amazonas. She lives with her partner, is 39 years old, and has three children - two sons and one daughter, all still school age. Miguelina is a very jovial woman, happy and optimistic, who began selling for another person until she got clients and decided to sell for herself. She saw that people were placing orders with her and the brother in law of a friend encouraged her to take the step. That is how she is now in business for herself and takes advantage of the offers to get the products and sell them at catalog prices, earning more. Now she has a very faithful clientele. She sells for cash and on credit, with payments daily, weekly, bi-monthly, or monthly. With this loan of 1000 Soles she will buy beauty products like colognes, nail polish, costume jewelry like earrings, necklaces,and rings. She will also buy cologne for men on special offer, and a display case to be able to show and care for her products. She wants to supply her business and provide good service to her clients so they can find what they need. Miguelina dreams of expanding this business and getting to be a star seller in order to earn good prizes. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping her to set up her business and also for helping the many women who want to advance themselves personally and in business.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy catalog products to increase her inventory

loans.name: Ghanem

texts.en: Ghanem is a hardworking man that strives every day to provide for his entire family, which consists of his wife and nine children. He manages a grocery store where he sells many staples, such as bread, juice, sweets, and other preserved foods. In order to purchase additional foodstuffs and increase his inventory, Ghanem is requesting a loan of $2000 USD. This micro-entrepreneur is qualified to receive this loan considering the profitability of his business, his determination, and his experience. Ghanem is counting on your help. Your support will really help him.

loans.use: Purchase additional foodstuffs and increase his inventory

loans.name: Celedonia

texts.en:
Celedonia M. is from the village of Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 59 years old. Celedonia is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Celedonia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting bananas, coconuts and vegetables for sale. Celedonia is also engaged in buying scrap materials and sells them to neighboring junk shops. Celedonia has been engaged in her businesses for over 20 years and earns approximately 7,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Celedonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celedonia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers for her farm such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Celedonia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

location.town: Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia L. is from the village of Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 52 years old. Alicia is married and has children. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling beverages including soft drinks and juices in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Alicia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: there make larger there business

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita M. is from the village of Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 45 years old. Marita is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Marita owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling cold beverages including soft drinks and juices in the local community. Marita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Marita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita L. is from the town of Mabini, Baliangao, Mis. Occ. She is 41 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Lolita owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for some years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2001, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used for house repair. This loan will be her 14th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth B. is from the town of Mabini, Baliangao, Mis. Occ. She is 31 years old, is married, and has seven school-aged children. Elizabeth owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for some years. In 2003, Elizabeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used for educational purposes. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use for educational purposes

loans.name: Zoya

texts.en:
Zoya is married with two children. She sells clothing at the central market in Novomoskovsk and has been in this business for ten years. During this time she has obtained many repeat clients that buy clothing from her.

There is a high demand for this type of goods, so Zoya is going to continue developing her business. She has got enough energy and enthusiasm for this.

Zoya would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to increase her assortment. She hopes to increase her sales and make additional income for her family.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en: Svetlana is married with one daughter. She sells all kinds of food in her own little store. The store is located in a good area that brings many clients. Svetlana has operated this business for 7 years. She always offers good and fresh products. Her clients know and value this. Svetlana is honest, entrepreneurial and hard working. She makes every effort to make her business a nice and attractive place for her customers. Svetlana is requesting a loan of 9,550 Ukranian hryvnia (or about $1150) to diversify her store's stock. She hopes to use the additional income to improve her business conditions.

loans.use: To diversify her store's stock

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married with two teenage children. She sells women's clothing at a small market in Melitopol city and has been in this business for 17 years. Large experience helps Valentina to choose right kind of inventories and make good sales. Valentina enjoys selling clothing; moreover, this business brings her stable income.
Valentina would like to borrow 12,900 UAH to purchase fall collection of women's clothing. She has used Hope loans before and considers them to be very helpful for her business.

loans.use: to purchase Fall collection

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en: Natalya is married with two adult children. She sells purses at a small market in Melitopol town. Natalya has been in this business for 16 years and she has been able to make a living for her family and raise her children. Natalya has developed her business by improving and expanding her kiosk, making it attractive to her clients. Natalya has used microloans in her business and always paid back on time. Natalya would like to borrow 12,800 UAH to purchase more inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Olena

texts.en: Olena is married. She sells cosmetics from a small space that she rents in a department store. She has been in this business for three years. The business has been a stable source of income for Olena and her family. Olena's business goal is to open a second location and increase sales. Olena has been using micro-loans and finds them very helpful for her business development. Olena would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Ada Graciela

texts.es:
La señora Ada Graciela  es una joven emprendedora entusiasta e ingeniosa, natural de Junín, tiene 25 años, conviviente y  con 2 hijos, su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona alta de huaycan, distrito de ate, departamento de lima.
Trabaja con EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad desde hace   2 años y 
 Desde hace 2  años y 6 meses, que se dedica a la venta de  pollo broster, a raíz que salio embarazada empieza a trabajar en este negocio, sale a vender todas las tardes hasta la media noche en la puerta de su casa y para generar mas ingreso  para su hogar se dedica también a la venta de ropa en forma ambulatoria, con los cuales hasta el momento con muchos esfuerzo logro realizar la compra de su terreno.
Con el reciente préstamo Ada invertirá en la compra de insumos para su negocio de pollo broster, como: aceite, harina, platos descartables, tenedores, bolsas, y otros.  Y también para la compra de ropa  de temporada, para ir mejorando su terreno el cual se encuentra ubicado en una zona agreste.
Ada tiene 2 anhelos en el futuro, uno es  abrir un  minimarket  ya que por su zona no hay este tipo de tiendas y el segundo es poder  construir su casa.
texts.en:
Sra. Ada Graciela is an enthusiastic and resourceful entrepreneur. She is 25 years old, in a common law marriage, and has 2 children. Originally from Junín, Sra. Ada Graciela lives in her own home in the area of Alta de Huaycan in Ate District, Department of Lima.

She has been working with EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad for 2 years. Her business started 2½ years ago, shortly after she became pregnant. She sells fried chicken every evening until midnight near the front of her home in order to generate more income. Sra. Ada Graciela also sells clothing door-to-door. She puts great effort into her work so that she can purchase her land.

She will use her current loan to buy supplies for her fried chicken business such as oil, flour, paper plates, forks, bags, and other items. In addition, she will purchase seasonal clothing for resale. She hopes to make improvements to her land since it is located in a rugged area.

Sra. Ada Graciela has two hopes for the future: open a mini-market since no such store exists in her area, and build a house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for her fried chicken business

loans.name: Nelvie

texts.en:
Nelvie B. is from the Philippine village of Gata Diot, Clarin, in the province of Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Nelvie is married and has three school-aged children. For over two years Nelvie has owned and run a sari-sari (a general store) in her local community. It is stocked with food and other necessities of daily life. She earns approximately 1000 PHP a month from this venture.

In 2009, Nelvie joined GDMPC to take advantage of its financial services. Nelvie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which she will use to expand her business and increase profits. Her goal is to improve her family’s living conditions. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nelvie from GDMPC.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her general store

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga is married to Pedor, who works as a passenger tricycle driver in downtown Cauayan. She is 61 years old, but despite her age, she is very strong and determined to manage her general store. They are blessed with five children ages 27 - 35. Their youngest child still lives with them. They live in Christine Village, which is approximately three kilometers from the center of Cauayan.  
	
Dominga wans a loan from Kiva of PHP 12,000 to use as additional capital for her store. Her weekly net business income is only PHP 500 (~ $10) on average. To increase her daily income, Dominga hopes that Kiva lenders will soon approve her loan.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en:
Vorn S., age 41, is married and has six children. She lives with her children in Kompong Chnang province. To make a living, she sells groceries in front of her house, typically earning an income of US $2.6 per day. The primary source of income is also generated by her husband who operates his business as motor-taxi driver, earning US $2.4 per day.  The family is also assisted by three of her children who are currently involved in the business the same to their father.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, S. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, S. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a new motorbike for one of her children to do business. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: motorbike purchase

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Yem S. is married and has two school-aged children. She lives with her husband (pictured in front of his house, which is rented to other people) and children in Phnom Penh. To make a living, she sells a type of "hard" alcoholic drink in front of her house, typically earning a gross income of US $3.00 per day. Their primary source of income is her husband’s business. He is a police officer and he rents part of his house to other people, earning collectively an income of US $5.00 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, S. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, S. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase more alcoholic drinks to expand her business. With the remainder of the money, she wants to repair her house. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more alcoholic drinks and repair her house

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine L. is from the village of Katipa. She is 48 years old. Josephine is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine harvests and sells ocean-caught fish in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Josephine from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila M. is from the village of Gata Diot in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old. Mila is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Mila raises pigs for sale. Mila has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Mila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mila is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supply. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mila from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supply

loans.name: Lorelyn

texts.en:
Lorelyn is engaged in hog-raising business. She is married to F. and is a good mother to her children. Her family lives in Barangay San Jose in Santiago City. She is happy that God blessed her with a family that gets along well together because she believes that good relationships are an important part of a successful life. 

The next step that she wants to pursue is expanding her business. However, due to a lack of financial capital, Lorelyn is now asking Kiva lenders for a loan of PHP 5,000 for the continuous growth of her hog-raising business. The amount will be used to buy feed and additional piglet. She hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her request.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Erenea

texts.en:
Erenea J. is from the village of Katipa. She is 61 years old. Erenea is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Erenea raises pigs for sale. Erenea is just starting this business.

In 2006, Erenea joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erenea has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Erenea is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Erenea from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Jinky Mabelle

texts.en:
Jinky Mabelle B. is from the village of Gata Diot in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Jinky Mabelle is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jinky Mabelle raises pigs for sale. Jinky Mabelle has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jinky Mabelle joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jinky Mabelle is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jinky Mabelle from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed

loans.name: Lailanie

texts.en:
Lailanie is 35 years old. She and her family are living in the village of Sitio Anguapan, Tumauini, Isabela.  They have four children, two them are in the high school level while the other two are in the elementary level. Lailanie is  helping her husband in supporting the needs of their family through her rice retailing business.  With this, she can provide her children with school allowance.  She and her husband are helping one another in reaching their goals for their family. 

Lailanie is again requesting to avail a loan amounting to PHP4, 000 to further improve her rice retailing business. She is planning to buy sacks of rice and to have a lot of stocks to able meet the needs of her customers in their village that will also increase her income.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia C. is from the village of Biasong. She is 55 years old. Aurelia is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Aurelia owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Aurelia has been engaged in her business for over 40 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Aurelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Aurelia is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Aurelia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia runs a general store. She also sells vegetables for additional income. She wanted her store to improve to meet the demands of her customers. She is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to use as additional capital. This will really help her business. 

Leticia is happily married to Roger and they are blessed with three children, two of whom are still in school. She wanted her two children to finish their studies, like her eldest. She hopes to give them a good future by providing for their educational needs. Letecia believes in this “praying without ceasing” to succeed in life.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Asuncion Gemma

texts.en:
Asuncion Gemma Lachica is a 45-year-old entrepreneur. She and her husband, Reiner, have six children, ages 5 to 19 years old. She wants all of her children to have their own career someday, so she wants to send all of them to school until they graduate from college. With only her husband’s income from his job as a utility worker, this may not turn into reality. Her husband’s income is sufficient only for food and other basic needs, but not when educational expenses are included. 

Asuncion Gemma wanted her own business so she could have her own income. Her motivation led her to Ahon Hirap, Inc. (ASHI). In 2003, Asuncion Gemma became a member of ASHI and has taken a loan to staring her business. She started with one business, but after several loans, Gemma now has several businesses. 

She raises hogs, cattle, and chickens, and she buys and sells rice. The profits from her livestock businesses have doubled. It takes four months to raise a pig, one year to raise a cow, and 45 days to raise a chicken. When the animal is mature, they are sold in the market, either alive or slaughtered. 

Asuncion Gemma sells rice from their own house. Her customers are her neighbors. She is now planning to buy and sell coconut from her house as well.
 
Through the loans that she can get from ASHI, if she maintain her good performance as a member, Asuncion Gemma foresees her businesses succeeding and growing.

loans.use: To finance her livestock and rice businesses and to start a coconut business

loans.name: Badamgarav

texts.en:
Badamgarav S. is a 48-year-old mother of four children, ages 16 - 30. She lives with her husband and four children in Ovorhangai Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. She financially supported her two oldest children so that they could receive higher education in university. They both successfully graduated from their universities and currently work in the professional arena. Her third son is currently a student in university in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her youngest daughter is 16 years old and goes to a local high school. 

Badamgarav has a small meat business. She has been renting a small stall in the local food market since 1996 and retailing meat, including mutton, beef and goat meat, to locals. She has been in the meat retail business for thirteen years and is quite well-known for selling good quality meat among local customers. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more meat for her business. She says that she needs to make more profit to pay  the university tuition for her two youngest children. Her ultimate goal is to see all four children get good higher education and pursue their dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for her business

loans.name: Dashnamjil

texts.en:
Dashnamjil O. is 26 years old. He is married and has an 8-year-old son. He currently resides with his mother, wife, brother and his son in Ovorhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His son has just started high school this year. Dashnamjil sells various women's and men's clothing at the local market. He bought a stall located inside the market and started selling clothes for locals. He usually purchases various women's and men's clothes from Ereen, China, a border town, from which many of Chinese cheap products are imported. Since the start of his business in 2004, he has been quite successful and has managed to expand his business by adding more varieties of clothes. In the near future, he would like add an even wider variety of clothes as locals' tastes and styles change with time. He says that he would like to expand his business aggressively and investigate different lucrative business opportunities in the town. 

He requests a loan to purchase more inventory of clothing for his retail business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of clothing for resale

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen is engaged in a rice selling business. AsiD. from this, she also sells vegetables in her village by going from one house to another. From this business, she is generating an income of PHP 250 a day, which is being used to sustain the needs of her family. Aileen aspires to have a more competent business to increase her daily income.  She knows that her business is the key for her to achieve her dreams. She hopes that it will grow and further expand for the benefit of her children. Thus, she is requesting a loan for additional business capital form Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 6,000. 

Aileen can be described as a responsible parent. She doesn’t want her children to starve, which is why she strives to become successful and proviD. them with everything they need. As much as possible, Aileen would like to proviD. not only the needs but also the wants of her children for them to be happy. Aileen is 26 years old and married to Regimar, a farmer. They are blessed with two children.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her food sales business

loans.name: Dorjsuren

texts.en:
Dorjsuren U. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Ovorhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Two of his children are university students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and the youngest daughter is 8 years old and goes to a local secondary school. Dorjsuren has an old Russian truck called a ZIL-130. He uses his truck for carrying freight in between different cities. He usually carries firewood and coal between his city and Ulaanbaatar. His wife is a big supporter of his business and helps in his business when she has time. Dorjsuren says that the main source of family income is the trucking business. He pays school tuitions for his two children with the business profits. He works hard to make sure that his children receive higher education without any financial strains. 

He requests a loan to repair his old truck and purchase necessary accessories for his truck.

loans.use: To repair his truck and purchase necessary accessories for his truck

loans.name: Azjargal

texts.en: G. Azjargal is 22 years old and lives with her husband, infant son, and mother-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  Azjargal currently operates a small electronic device and tools selling business out of a rented stall at Norjin, a busy trade plaza in the city. She started the business with her husband right after graduating high school  Today, her mother-in-law also helps out by watching the baby for them when they are at work. There is nearly no competition in the area, which makes her stall very popular and allows her to move her goods quickly. Azjargal has found much success with her business, and her husband also drives a taxi to supplement their income.  She is currently  planning to open a second stall to expand her business, but that is not her ultimate dream. "I'd like to one day have my own electric appliances store", she says. Azjargal is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~690 USD) loan to purchase a variety of electronic goods to sell at her stall.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of electronic goods

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita D. P., 42, is a rice grower in Trento, Agusan Del Sur. She has three children and is married to a farmer. She tills a 3-hectare farm with her husband, of course. She said that this is her fourth loan with CEVI  and hopefully, she will be able to grow her business more. 

Like the previous proposition, she needs a loan to get along with the finances on her farm. She definitely needs Php 13,000 to buy fertilizers and chemicals. 

She wishes for her farming business to flourish and to buy more farms. She said she likes CEVI because they are not just giving loans but bringing education to them as well.

loans.use: To buy seeds and other farm needs

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn L. is from the village of Lao Sta. Cruz. She is 31 years old. Analyn is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Analyn owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Analyn has been in business for over seven years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Analyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Analyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Analyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business of harvesting and selling fish

loans.name: Boldbayar

texts.en: Boldbayar M. is a humble, helpful and open-minded person. He lives with his wife, Badamtsetseg, and 3-year-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in his father-in-law's house. Boldbayar currently operates a transportation business in the city using a van he owns. Every day, he makes ten trips between two transportation terminals in the city. His wife works along with him, collecting fares and announcing stops as he drives. They enjoy the work, however, his wife's voice is starting to tire after years of loudly announcing route stops.  Boldbayar started his business in 2006, after obtaining a loan to purchase his van. He has found much success as a driver, however, he recently had to purchase a bus as the city government plans to enact a law forbidding the use of vans for transportation in the city. He hopes to use future profits from the business to provide his family with their own house. He is requesting a  2,000,000 tugrug (~1,380 USD) loan to purchase a new van motor and four wheels to keep his van operating efficiently.

loans.use: To purchase a new motor and wheels for his van

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is 46 years old and is married to a fisherman. She has four children ranging in age from 15 to 24 years old. She joined Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) in 2003, requesting a business loan because she has to augment her husband's sporadic income to be able to send all of their children to school until college. Her loan was used to finance her husband's livelihood of fishing. It has been nine years that this business has been Jocelyn's main source of income. She sells the fish her husband has caught every day in the market. Jocelyn has been able to have a hog fattening (pig raising) business from her profits. The profits she has with this business are twice as much as the capital. Income with this business is every four months and timely to support the semester tuition fees of her three children in college. 

With the loan she is applying for now, Jocelyn plans to expand the fishing business and also to finance her hog fattening business. She knows she can afford to pay larger amounts of weekly amortization in ASHI if her business grows. Another factor that influences her courage is her very supportive husband and cooperative children.

loans.use: Will be used to financing her fishing business. Small portion will also be used to finance her pig raising business.

loans.name: Eusebio

texts.en:
Eusebio B. is 58 years old and owns a 3-hectare farm in Trento, Agusan del Sur. He has been farming since 1960. He has six children and a supportive wife who also helps him with managing the farm. He is a proud CEVI client. He said he has been requesting loans from CEVI for a quite long time already and is currently hoping to get his seventh loan.

He told CEVI that he needs additional capital to run his farm. He said that he definitely needs PHP 15,000 to be able to buy good quality rice seeds and to pay the laborers who help prepare the land.

He is pleased with services of Community Economic Ventures Inc. He still would want to request its services in the future.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds for his farm and be able to pay laborers

loans.name: Otgon

texts.en: Otgon B. is 33 years old and lives with her husband and 2 year-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her husband currently operate a leather and cloth sewing business out of their ger (Mongolian traditional tent).  The sewing machine and pattern design board occupies much of the space in their home.  Otgon started the business in 2003 and has found much success. Their main product is leather coats, that upon completion, are taken to the local market to be sold. Her husband also operates a taxi to supplement their income. Otgon and her husband are both  very hardworking and make a good team. At the business her husband makes all of the patterns and she does the stitching  Currently, they can produce 4 leather coats per week. They are working hard to create a happy, healthy, and successful life for their  daughter,  Uyanga. “We are working for our daughter's future” she said. In the near future, Otgon hopes to rent a larger workshop to increase the efficiency and capacity of the operation.  Her long-term goal is to one day start her own factory. She is requesting a 1,300,000 tugrug (~ 898 USD) loan to purchase more leather and pay the first few months rent at her new workshop.

loans.use: to purchase more leather and pay the first few months rent at her new workshop.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia is 33 years old and married to Marcelo. The couple manages their small businesses, which are farming and hog raising. Her husband manages their small farm while she manages their hogs. They live in the village of San Jose in Santiago City, Isabela. Lack of capital made her decide to borrow a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000. She will use the loan to purchase feed for her hogs. 

Leticia is the mother of two children. The eldest is currently in college while the youngest is in the primary level. She hopes to provide the best education for her children, which is why she keeps doing what is best for her business.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her hogs

loans.name: Junita

texts.en:
Junita A., 58 years old, owns a one-hectare farm in Trento, Agusan del Sur. She has two children and a supportive husband who also helps her manage the farm.

She needs additional capital to run her farm. She said that she will need Php 13,000 to be able to buy good quality rice seed and pay the laborers who help prepare the land.

She likes the services of Community Economic Ventures Inc. She said she would like to use these services in the future.

loans.use: To buy seed and pay for laborers

loans.name: Darisuren

texts.en: Darisuren S. is 54 years old and lives with her two children in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. Her daughter is a university student and her son attends a local secondary school. Darisuren started her business in 1985, making deels (Mongolian tradional clothes). She has been very successful, and attributes this to being very hardworking. Today, her business capital has increased to a level exceeding 600,000 tugrugs (~ 414 USD). As a single mother, Darisuren's business is very important for her and her family. She says, "As my business grows, I hope to provide my children with a quality education." Darisuren requests a 1,000,000 tugrug (~ 690 USD) loan to purchase raw materials, such as silk and fabrics, for her deel business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials, such as silk and fabrics

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 50 years old. She works as a fish and meat vendor in her village in San Jose, Santiago City. She is already a widow and thus serves as a mother and father to her son, Orlando. She is glad that through her perseverance, she has been able to give her son the education he wanted. She is also thankful that through the business, she was able to support their daily needs.  

She hopes to sustain the business because it is really a big help for them to surpass financial difficulties, thus she would like to request a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional business capital.

loans.use: To finance her fish and meat vending business

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en:
Melodina P. is from the village of Lao Sta Cruz. She is 39 years old. Melodina is married and has seven school-age children. To make a living, Melodina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Melodina has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Melodina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melodina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Melodina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Melodina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital for her general store

loans.name: Dorj

texts.en:
S. Dorj is 59 years old and lives with his wife and four adult children in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. His wife is retired and his youngest two children are university students. Since 2002, Dorj has operated a transportation business in his town and has gained much experience. 

Dorj is very hardworking, and because of this, his businesses has been very successful. Dorj has used the profits from his business to improve his family's quality of life and send two of his children to college. His family has always worked together and grows vegetables at their home to supplement their income.

Dorj has proven to be a good businessman, but he is a “family man” first. He says, "My main goal is to provide for a good education for my children." He requests a 1,200,000 tugrug loan to restore and repair his old vehicle.

loans.use: To restore and repair his old vehicle

loans.name: Jellypie

texts.en:
Jellypie B., 49, is a rice grower and the mother of five children. She started farming in the 1980s, but almost forgot the exact year when we asked her when she learned to farm. 

She is requesting a loan of Php 13,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy seeds, preferably of good quality, and to pay the laborer who toiled hard preparing the farm for the next planting.

Hopefully her loan will result in a better harvest so that she will be able to help augment their family income.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and payment for the laborers

loans.name: Enkhbayar

texts.en: Enkhbayar S. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He has lived in Arkhangai with his family now for the past 16 years. Both of his daughters currently attend local secondary schools. Enkhbayar currently operates a meat retail business out of a rented stall at the local market. He has gained many years of experience in the business and has always been able to rely on the help of his family. Enkhbayar started his meat business in 1999 with capital of only 30,000 tugrugs (~21 USD), as this was the only money that he had. The business has since found much success and has been in stable operations for many years. Due to all of his hard-work, his business capital now exceeds 600,000 tugrugs. For the future, Enkhbayar hopes to expand his business. He says, “I wish to own my own workplace and buy a car”. It is also important that he provides for his children's future education.  He  is requesting a loan of 600, 000 tugrigs (approx.$415 USD) to purchase meat for his business.

loans.use: to purchase meat

loans.name: Vergelita

texts.en: 40-year-old Vergelita and her farmer husband are into a rice production (rice farming) business seven years now. Profits from this business was used by Vergelita to send her four children to school. Two now are in college and two are in high school. Vergelita wants to grow their rice production business to be able to enhance their profit and to be able to send her two younger children to college in a couple of years. She started with this business through a loan from Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI)when she became a member in 2005 therefore, she will also be using her loans to enhance her business. Now, Vergelita intended to use her loan for buying a hand tractor and rice seedlings for the and season of planting. Though harvest of harvest of rice takes place every after five months, Vergelita's husband support her weekly payment in ASHI through his fishing business which is daily. Verogelita chooses longer mode of payment to avoid overburdening herself with bigger payments weekly versus her weekly income. Fortunately, with this principle she has, in all her loans, she has maintained a very good performance.

loans.use: Will be used to enhance her rice farming business.

loans.name: Munkh-Erdene

texts.en:
Munkh-Erdene B. is 22 years old and lives with his wife and infant daughter in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He currently operates a general goods retail business along with his wife in their town. Munkh-Erdene started his retail business in 2008 with capital of 500,000 tugrugs (about $345). His business has found much success in a short period of time. Today, his business capital exceeds 1,300,000 tugrugs (about $898). 

In the future, he hopes to use his profits to expand his business by increasing the variety of goods that he sells. Munkh-Erdene attributes his success to his hardworking and modest business style. His dream is to one day own his own workspace and to purchase a car. 

He is requesting a 1,200,000 tugrug loan to procure more goods to sell at his business.

loans.use: to procure more goods

loans.name: Ochgerel

texts.en:
Ochgerel B. is a 30-year-old single mother who lives with her three daughters in the Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. Her two oldest daughters currently attend secondary school and the youngest has not yet reached school age. Ochgerel, together with her sister, operates a mobile commodities-trade business in her town. By driving her vehicle through the Arkhangai countryside, she exchanges commodities and dairy products which she sells at markets in the province capital and Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city.
 
Ochgerel started her business in 2005 with capital of 300,000 tugrugs. Her business has found success and the profits have greatly improved her family's quality of life. As result of her hard work, today, her business capital exceeds 1,200,000 tugrugs (approximately $828). 

Ochgerel's ultimate goal is to provide a good education for her children. She is hoping to one day expand her business to help accomplish this goal. She says, “I hope (to) expand my business even more and own a permanent workspace.” She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more goods to sell.

loans.use: Purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn T., 35-years old, rice farmer started to worry about the growing finance sin their home. She has four children and a very supportive husband. She learned to farm when she was just a little kid, from her parents. But when she got married she was able to apply what she lerned in her childhood days. 

To buy seeds, pesticides and payment for the laborers are the real purpose why she would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community economic Ventures Inc. Hopefully, this would be her 5th loan in CEVI that will truly help her augment their income. 

She said, she likes the services of CEVI because of low interest rate of 2% a month which is very low that every borrowers could afford to repay their loans.

loans.use: To buy seeds and pesticides and payment for the laborer

loans.name: Tuvshintugs

texts.en: Tuvshintugs N. is 44 year old and lives with his wife and two sons in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. His oldest son is a 19 year old university student, and his youngest is an 18 year old  high school student. The family is very happy in Arkhangai and has lived in their house for 10 years. Tuvshintugs operates both a clothing retail and taxi business in his town. He sells clothes through a rented stall at the local market and uses his own car for his taxi service. Tuvshintugs, in an effort to make a better living, started the clothing business in 1997 with capital of 100,000 tugrugs (~ 69 USD). With the profits from this business, he was able to buy a car and started the taxi service in 2003. Both businesses have brought him success and have greatly improved his family's quality of life. Tuvshintugs attributes his success to being a very open-minded businessman, and today, his business capital exceeds 600,000 tugrugs.  For the future, Tuvshintugs says, “I dream of owning my own store”.  He is requesting a 800,000 tugrug (~ 552 USD)loan for purchasing new car parts for his taxi business.

loans.use: purchasing new spare parts

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry Cabrilllos is a CEVI client who has invested in planting rice to raise his family. He has received five loans with CEVI and wishes to take other loans to help support his rice farm, which he inherited from his parents.

He would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy rice seeds and herbicides and to pay the labor fees of other farmers who helped prepare the land. 

He said he likes the services of CEVI. He likes the interest rate because it is very low so that all borrowers can afford it.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and herbicides and to pay for labor

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Through the initiative and patience of Margarita she is able to improve her mushroom production business that is located in the village of Isidro Paredes of Diffun Quirino. The business is situated in their backyard that is why she is able to maintain it well to produce more kilos of mushrooms every week. In connection with this she is asking for financial supports from Kiva lenders to be able to further improve her business and sells bigger amount of mushrooms to her costumers. She wanted to borrow the amount of PHP5, 000 as additional business capital. 

Margarita is already 45 years old. She is married to Francisco M. Sr. They are blessed with four children, one is already married. Her youngest child just finished a two- year course in college. Margarita expects a higher income in her next harvest and hopes that with the financial support from Kiva lenders, her mushroom business will grow.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Ghullam Sedeq Group

texts.en:
Ghullam Sedeq is the group leader of Ghullam Sedeq group. There are four members in this group and each wants a loan to expand her or his business.

Ghullam Sedeq wants a loan for a general store; he would like to expand his business and buy more materials to attract clients. Fazelah wants a loan for her husband who has a general store; her husband wants to expand his business and buy more materials, especially things which are more in demand. Marzya wants a loan for her bakery. And Salema wants to take a loan for her husband’s business, which is a car parts shop.

They are requesting a group loan of 56,000 Afghani. They are very happy about this small loans process in Afghanistan and especially want to thank Kiva lenders around the world.

loans.use: To expand a grocery store

loans.name: Amelyn

texts.en:
Amelyn has been a good client of Kiva loans. With the help of the lenders from her first loan, she was able to provide for the needs of her children and is very thankful for the financial support given to her. She is asking to again borrow PHP 5,000.00 in order to further improve her vegetable vending business.

Amelyn is 27-years old and married to Oscar, a driver. They have three children and two are studying. Princess Joy, seven-years old, is the eldest. Precious May is six-years old and both of the girls are in elementary school. The youngest, Clarence Jay, is eight months old. Amelyn hopes to improve their standard of living by patiently helping her husband through her small business. She hopes that the loan will be granted in order to help her business grow.

loans.use: To improve vegetable selling business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S., age 52, is married and has three children. She lives with her husband and her children in Phnom Penh City. To make a living, her husband works as a construction builder, earning approximately US $5 per day. This amount of income is the primary source of income of the family. Moreover, two of S.'s children are employed in a garment factory and at a construction site with an income of US $2 per day each to help the family.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, S. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, S. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work not only in the town but also the other places in the province. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: motorbike purchase

loans.name: Seang

texts.en:
Seang T., age 53, is married and lives with her husband (pictured) in Phnom Penh City. Her husband is employed as a construction worker earning about US $7 per day which is the primary source of income for the family.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has made it a difficult economic year for much of the country, T. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, T. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US $600 in order to purchase a motorbike for her husband to be able to commute to work not only in the town but also to other places in the province. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to increase the standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en: Josefina is a 49-year-old single woman who aspires of becoming an entrepreneur. She lives with her mother, brother, niece and nephew. Her family has been into rice production (rice farming) business since 25 years ago. Josefina's 81-year-old mother and her brother's children are dependent to her and her brother financially. Income of her brother from fishing is so insufficient to sustain the family and also the business. Josefina wants to finance their family business managed by her brother therefore she joined ASHI just this month be able to get a loan. She is hoping that through loans she will be getting from ASHI after paying the other, her family's rice production business would grow and that she can help her brother send her children to school until college.She also wants to give her mother a quality kind of life while she still lives.

loans.use: To finance a rice production (rice farming ) business.

loans.name: Fidela

texts.en:
Fidela A. is a 63-year-old widow from Mulawin, Maricaban, Pasay City. She has five dependents with the eldest already making a living and helping her augment their basic daily needs.

Fidela runs a community pharmacy selling generic medicines at affordable prices. She started this business last year. Fidela makes a monthly profit of more than P7,000. She laments, however, that come rainy season, sales decrease as she has to close her store because of the perennial flooding in the city and the flood waters that run through her pharmacy.

Since 2001, she has been an active member of Kiva partner the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and has benefited from its many programs and services empowering women in poor communities.

Fidela is asking for a loan of P10,000 in order to buy more medicine to sell at her pharmacy. She is dependent on income from the business to buy medication for one of her children who has epilepsy. She would also like to refurbish her pharmacy to address the perennial flood problem that adversely affects her business.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase medicine to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen N. is a fish vendor from Isla 2 Neighborhood, Maricaban, Pasay City. She is 45 years old. Her husband, Josias, 51, works as a cook. They have three children. Helen has been selling fresh and dried fish house-to-house in her neighborhood for two years, earning 8,000 pesos per month. As she relies on sunshine to dry her fish, Helen's sales, and not her fish, dry up when it rains. Helen is also concerned that going house-to-house in poor weather is causing her frequent colds and fevers. She hopes to have her own stall in the market so she won’t need to walk the streets everyday to sell fish. She is hopeful her loans with CCT will help her address her concerns. Helen joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2008 and is now on her 3rd loan. She needs a loan of P8,000 to buy more fresh fish in bulk to dry under the sun. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish in bulk

loans.name: Divina

texts.en: Divina L., 58, has been in business for the last ten years. She lives in Maricaban, Pasay City. Her husband, Hernando, 59, manages his own welding shop. Two of their three children are already working and help support their parents. Divina sets up a table in an alley near her house and sells food items that she cooks every day. Her location enjoys a lot of traffic allowing her to earn close to P12,000 per month. Recently, she started selling charcoal (household fuel for cooking) to customers. Divina joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in early 2008 and has since been enjoying the many benefits it provides to its members. Divina recently applied for a new loan of P14, 000 so she can buy more charcoal which she has found to be a good source of additional income. She hopes to someday turn her stall into a full-blown restaurant. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane M. is from the village of Katipa. She is 35 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Mary Jane owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2005, Mary Jane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Kamelah Group

texts.en:
Kamelah wants a loan for her husband’s vegetable business and Madena wants a loan for her son’s business selling sticks. Pakey wants a loan for her husband’s general store. Rayhana wants a loan for a tailoring business.

Kamelah is the leader of this four member group. Each member wants to take a loan for expanding her business and they are requesting a total loan of 20,000 afghani. They are very thankful to AFS and to Kiva lenders who are able to support all the people in and around Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy materials for their businesses

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en:
Ouk N., age 27, is married and has four children. She lives with her husband and her children in Phnom Penh City. She is employed in a local garment factory, earning approximately US$2 per day. To make a living, her husband operates a business as a motor-taxi driver, earning US$5 per day which is the primary source of income for her family.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, N. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, N. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US$800 to buy a new motorbike for her husband because the old motorbike is usually broken and consumes a lot of gasoline. By doing so, she believes that her husband will be able to generate maximum income to raise a good standard of living for the family.

loans.use: To buy her husband a new motorbike for his business

loans.name: Lucrecia

texts.en: Lucrecia P., at age 53, is a tireless entrepreneur. Her husband, Leticio, (seen with Lucrecia in the photo), also 53 years old, is a carpenter and also farms root crops. They have six children. Lucrecia and Leticio have no idle time. They make a living from almost anything they touch. While Leticio attends to their cassava plantation, Lucrecia takes care of their hogs until they are ready for slaughter and the meat is sold to their neighbors. Lucrecia also cooks home-made rice cakes and native delicacies which she sells in the streets every day. They earn P25,000 per month from these combined business activities. Lucrecia joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. She loves the camaraderie of the women entrepreneurs. She is applying for a new loan of P16,000 which she will use to fund her rice cake business. She also plans to buy additional swine and stock-up on feed for the pigs. Lucrecia has been praying for her own stall in the nearby market. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To fund her rice cake business and to buy additional pigs and pig feed

loans.name: Tith

texts.en:
Tith S., age 49, is married and has three children. She lives with her husband and her children in Phnom Penh City. She is engaged in a business of sewing and designing clothes at her home, earning approximately 3 USD per day. To make a living, her husband has to commute from place to place to work as a construction worker, earning 8 USD per day, which is the primary source of income for her family. The family is also assisted by two of her children who are employed in a local garment factory with an income of 2 USD per day each.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, S. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, S. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of 1000 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate in an additional business as a motor-taxi driver. With the remainder of the loan, she wants to buy wood for her husband to use in the construction business. By doing so, she believes that her husband will be able to generate maximum income to increase the standard of living for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for a taxi business and wood for use in a construction business

loans.name: Maryam Group

texts.en:
Maryam wants a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to expand and improve her business by buying a new machine to attract more customers and to become a good business dealer. Roshan Ghull wants a loan for a video shop. Bibi Nadera wants a loan for her carpet weaving business. Bibi Shekarya wants a loan for her husband’s general store.

Maryam is the leader of this four member group. They each want to expand their businesses. They have requested a group loan of 56,000 afghani. They all want to thank Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand a tailoring business

loans.name: Nen

texts.en:
Nen T. V., age 37, is a widow and has a young child. To make a living she is engaged in the business of selling vegetables (bean sprouts) at a market in the city, earning approximately US$8 per day. This amount is the primary source of income for the family. The family income is also assisted by her child who is currently employed in a local garment factory with an income of US$2 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for businesses in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, V. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, V. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase more vegetables and a motorbike she will use to purchase vegetable to sell.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her business and more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas K. H., age 32, is married and has two children. She lives with her husband and her children in Phnom Penh City. To make a living, she is engaged in the business of selling Chinese noodles and fried rice at her house, earning approximately US$10 per day. This amount is the primary source of income of the family. Her husband works for a private company as an accountant, earning an income of US$8 per day.
