The financial crisis has been difficult for businesses in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, H. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, H. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase more food and supplements for her food shop. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To buy more food and supplements for her restaurant

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao C., age 61, is a widower and has five children. He lives with his children in Phnom Penh City. To make a living, he works for a poor community, earning approximately US$4 per day. The family is also assisted by Chea Mariya, one of his children, who runs a business in front of her house with her husband (pictured). Mariya's husband is a skillful mechanic, and he is able to generate an income of US$10 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, Cheab included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, Cheab is seeking to increase his income. He is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase motorbike spare parts for his son-in-law to expand his business. By doing so, he believes that his son-in-law will be able to raise a good standard of living for the family.

loans.use: To buy motorbike spare parts for his son-in-law's business

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en: Nelly D. is 48 years old. She lives in Maricaban, Pasay City with her husband Elvin, 30, who works as a driver. They have a child in elementary school. Nelly opened a sari-sari (general) store three years ago, the same year she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. Loans from the cooperative have helped her grow her store and helped her meet her family's daily, basic needs. From her sari-sari store, Nelly has a monthly profit of P7,500. Nelly is working hard to support her child's education. She wants to see her child finish college, which Nelly wasn't able to do herself. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Nel

texts.en:
Nel E., age 44, is married and has three children. He lives with his wife and children (pictured) in Phnom Penh City. He is a construction foreman, earning approximately US$8 per day which is the primary source of income for his family. To make a living, his wife prepares fabrics at her house with an income of US$2 per day. The family is assisted by one of E.'s children who is currently employed in a local garment factory with an income of US$3 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, E. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, E. is seeking to increase his income. He is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase wood for his construction business and pieces of fabrics. By doing so, he believes that he will be able to raise a good standard of living for his family.

loans.use: To buy buy wood for his construction business and pieces of fabric for his wife's business

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
Kem T., age 29, is a widow and has a child. She lives with her child in Phnom Penh City. To make a living, she operates a business producing Cambodian traditional cake, earning approximately 4 USD per day. This amount of income is the primary source of income for the family.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, T. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, T. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of 500 USD to purchase rice and sugar to manufacture more cakes to sell. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to generate more income and save more money for her child's education.

loans.use: To buy rice and sugar

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Some people make an early choice of their career, become steadfast and pursue this path. They know what they are going to do to earn their livelihood. The group's leader, Damira, is among them. A 36-year-old hairdresser and mother of three children, Damira has dedicated many years to her occupation. She was just a 16-year-old girl when she finished hairdressing courses. She swiftly learned all aspects of her profession, providing all kinds of hair-related services: various haircuts, hair dyeing styles, hair setting, and hairdos (e.g., waved, curled, perm, marcel waves, etc.). She has become an A1 specialist. She has assigned a room and adjusted it to be a hairdressing salon. By saving her profits, she recently purchased a car. Damira feels that she can do better and that she is just not using all the opportunities. So, she has planned to make an improvement at her salon. She is firmly convinced that if she furnishes and decorates her salon, more customers will be attracted. Damira needs a loan to equip her salon with shelves and wallpaper. In the near future, she is going to expand her business by taking on a few apprentices. People do grow when they have a vision of how to do that.

Damira’s partners:
Gulzina, age 44 and mother of two children, works as a cleaner at a casino. She needs a loan to buy building materials for her kitchen and to buy a chandelier.
Jumabu is age 56. She and her husband are farmers. They have three children. They need a loan to buy fuels and lubricants, as well as to pay for transportation services and to pay workers for harvesting.
Edilbek, age 35, is married and has one child. He works as an assistant station-master in "Tuz" substation. He needs a loan to place a crusher at the same substation and to buy some cement for installing it.
Aida, age 38, is a housewife. She sells milk and also produces cheese and butter. She needs a loan to buy a milk cow.
Nazgul, age 38, is married. She has three children. To make a living she sells yogurt, sour cream and cottage cheese. She hopes to get a loan to buy a milk cow.

Where Did This Loan Come From?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of a 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable, to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To equip a hairdressing salon with shelves and wallpaper

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda, 51, married to Rodrigo, a tricycle driver in area, is the mother of seven children, four already married and three still living with them in Christine Village, Cauayan City, Isabela.

Yolanda owns a snack-vending business, selling items such as rice cakes. Sometimes she also sells frozen fish and meat. She can earn a weekly income of PHP500.00, which is not enough to meet the needs of their family. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of PHP8, 000 as business capital to further improve her business and income. Yolanda is very optimistic that her dreams will become a reality.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida D., 48, from a large community in Pasay City, is married to Diosdado, also 48 years old, a pedicab driver and volunteer as a community peace-keeper. They have two children, one in high school and one in college.

Aida owns and manages two pedicabs, including the one driven by her husband, and she also sells food along the street from a long table. Her net earnings per month from these businesses amount to P11,000. During the rainy season (from June through December), floods prevent Aida from setting up her food stall, thus reducing her income. Because they are in demand in her community, especially during rainy days when streets are flooded, Aida has applied for a P8,000 loan to buy another pedicab.

Aida joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2008. She is hopeful that with the profits from her growing business and the help of loans from CCT, she will soon realize her dream of owning a motorized tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar).

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase a new pedicab

loans.name: Anelyn

texts.en:
Anelyn C. is from the village of Lao Sta Cruz. She is 30 years old. Anelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Anelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Anelyn has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Anelyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Anelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa B. is a 70-year-old widow who lives in Maricaban, Pasay City. She lost her husband this summer and now lives with her only child. Luisa owns a general store located just in front of her house. She also has a burger stand. She has been in these businesses for three years and earns P10,000 per month. Since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2001, Luisa has received a lot of blessings. CCT loans have helped her grow her businesses allowing her to meet her basic family needs. She now plans to expand her business by purchasing a new burger grill and has applied for a P18,000 loan to buy the grill. Luisa dreams of owning a big grocery store in the future. She hopes to live a longer life so she can continue serving God and her community. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy a new burger grill

loans.name: Aihan's Group

texts.en: The leader of this group is Aihan, a thirty-eight year old mother of three children. Her eldest daughter and eight-year old son go to school, and her little son goes to kindergarten. Her husband is a welder. Showing thrift and patience Aihan and her husband managed to save some funds, namely $715, from her husband’s earnings and opened up a business in a market. Now Aihan sells women’s clothes. The fact, that Aihan has started making profits and bringing money home has greatly influenced their lives in a good way. Though her monthly income barely reaches $120, at least Aihan has become able to feed her children better. At this moment Aihan urgently needs a loan to purchase school uniforms and more women’s clothes, because very soon in September school season starts. Her future plans are to buy premises for opening a cash-and-carry shop. Aihan’s partners are Aisada, Adylbek and Dinara. Aisada, 33, sells women’s clothes in a market. She has three children and the little one is just two and half years old. A $350 loan allowed her to start her business. Now she makes well over a half of that sum each month. Aisada needs a loan to purchase more school uniforms and women’s clothes. Her dream is to buy a big house for her family. Adylbek, 45, is married. To provide for his wife and granddaughter he works as a taxi-driver. He worked hard in Russia and upon return to his homeland was able to buy a car. Now he earns around $240 a month. Adylbek wants to have an additional source of money and has decided to purchase livestock: sheep and a milk cow. He hopes to get a loan for this purpose. Dinara, 39, is married and is the mother of three children. Her husband is a farmer, whereas she sells men’s and women’s clothes and shoes. Her business has given her an opportunity to buy a car: a micro-bus. Recently they moved from a house to a flat. Dinara needs a loan to purchase school uniforms. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase school uniforms and more women’s clothes for the upcoming season

loans.name: Noli

texts.en:
Noli is 20 years old and already married to Dority, a very supportive wife who works as an AVON dealer. They have a four-year-old son named Daniel and live a peaceful and happy life in Calamagui 1st, Ilagan, Isabela, a community with a big population near Ilagan town proper.

Noli has operated a passenger tricycle in their village since purchasing his own tricycle four years ago. He is now requesting a loan of PHP8,000 to be used for the maintenance of their tricycle and to support his wife's business. He wants his business to become productive for the welfare of his family.

loans.use: Additional capital for maintenance and business support

loans.name: Mamor Agha Jan Group

texts.en:
Mamor Agha jan is the group leader of Mamor Agha Jan group. There are three members in this group and they each want to take a loan to progress their business and make it larger. So they are requesting a group loan of 30,000 Afghani.
pary Jan  wants to take a loan for her son’s business of general store.
Mamor Agha Jan wants to take a loan for his business mechanic shop. Also Nor Rabkhan wants to take a loan for his business of repallring car. 
They are very thankful to Kiva lenders who are able to support the whole world.

loans.use: they are support their families

loans.name: Kulmira's Group

texts.en:
Nowadays, time has made people such as Kulmira, the leader of this group, and her family members become Jacks of all trades. Conducting business at home, her husband regularly works as a welder, while Kulmira trades in milk, buying from villagers and reselling it in a market. One of her sons mends cell phones and the other son sells milk and cheese. As well, the whole family receives orders and provides Western-style renovation services. The family’s eight-year activity has allowed them to buy a car and furniture. Kulmira’s current income is around $240 per month.

Now, the next project is to buy a milk cow. Because Kulmira values time and does not want to lose time saving money, she hopes to get a loan to hasten the process of acquiring the cow. In the future, she has pretty determined plans of opening a cheese-producing factory, increasing the number of livestock, and buying new furniture for the house.

Kulmira’s partners are Kulsina, Salyi and Nurgul. Kulsina, 59, married to a metalworker, has five children. In addition to being a housewife, she manages to keep a cow and four sheep for reselling. Even though they do not have much livestock, they have been able to increase their number. She is requesting a loan to purchase sheep.

Salyi, 51, is the divorced mother of a 19-year-old-daughter. To earn a living, she sells traditional items of manufacture, beddings and pillows, a craft she learned from her relatives. Salyi requests a loan to buy a sewing machine and fabric.

Nurgul, 34, is a married mother of two children. Nurgul’s husband vulcanizes tires, while she manufactures traditional articles, a skill she learned from her mother. She is in need of a loan to buy materials for manufacture. Her plan is to expand her range of goods, buy an electric sewing machine, and renew the furniture.

====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow to increase milk sales

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
“Patience is the key to success,” says Remedios A.. She manages a general store business in their village in San Jose, Santiago City.

Remedios’ store still lacks different commodities that are in demand by her customers. Therefore, she would like to borrow PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders to buy additional merchandise like coffee, sugar, spices, canned and bottled goods and other merchandise that will also increase her profit. She hopes that Kiva lenders will approve her loan request.

Remedios is the mother of three, and she is thankful that, despite the difficulties of life, she is able to sustain their basic necessities and support the education of her youngest child.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza M. is from the village of Lopez Jaena. She is 37 years old, is married, and has eight school-aged children. Liza owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Liza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Liza is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Mwajuma's Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is a member of the Chapakazi borrower group in Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 21 years old woman,she is single .

Mwajuma started her own cafe business selling food 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Mwajuma`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000Tsh in order to buy more commodities to her food business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Mwajuma hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Martha is another member of the same borrower group she also requested the loan in order to expand her charcoal business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for food

loans.name: Rosemelita

texts.en:
Rosemelita is a vegetable vendor, selling her own harvested vegetables in their village. She wants to increase her merchandise and so she would like to borrow PHP 6,000. With the loan, she can start to buy more vegetables that she can sell not only in their village but also in the market for a bigger income. She is hoping that lenders will grant her request for her business to become sustainable.

Rosemelita lives peacefully in their village of Capellan, Ilagan, Isabela, together with her husband who patiently works as a farmer. They have five children and two are still studying.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Charlita

texts.en:
Charlita is a retailer of cell phone loads in their village at Barangay Antagan 1st of Tumauini, Isabela. She wants to borrow PHP 6,000 from Kiva lenders for her load-retailing business. Both SMART and GLOBE subscribers are being served by Charlita in their village, bringing easier communication for relatives, friends and lovers that are away from their loved ones.

Sometimes, due to other financial needs of her family, Charlita was not able to buy load wallets for the retailing of cell phone loads. Thus, she wants to borrow from Kiva lenders to maintain the business and someday be able to expand in other networks like Sun Cellular. She plans to utilize the entire loan for her business if her request is granted.

Charlita is already 47 years old. She is married to a farmer who also works as a house carpenter. They have four children namely: Ferdinand, the eldest, a high school graduate and already married; the same with their second child Ryan;  third is Romer, who has stopped studying; and lastly is Grave, their youngest, who is currently enrolled in third year high school. Charlita really wanted to send them to finish their schooling in college, but it is their own decision to stop in their studies. She is hoping that her youngest child will earn a degree in college to be able to have a much better future than what they have at present.

loans.use: To buy more cellphone loads to sell

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine S. is from the village of Lao Sta Cruz. She is 25 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Catherine owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2008, Catherine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Catherine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Sayraw Group

texts.en: Sayraw is the group leader of Sayraw group. They are three members in this group. Each of them wants to take a loan for progress their business and make it larger. So they are requested a group of loan 42000 Afghani. Sayraw wants to take a loan for the business of embroidery. Saeda wants to take a loan for her husband who has P.C.O. D. M. wants to take a loan for the business of general store. So they are very happy from this process of loan in Afghanistan.

loans.use: For expanding business

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza runs a general store business situated in front of their house. Aside from selling different groceries, she also retails plastic wares like durabox (plastic cabinets), bamboo sala sets (living room furniture), other appliances, and a lot more. She lives in a place away from the town proper so she thought of selling those items to reach customers in their distant and remote village of Capellan, Ilagan, Isabela. She uses her income in sustaining the educational needs of her two children. 

Analiza is asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to be used as her additional business capital to buy more items to be displayed just beside their house so as to grow her business.

Analiza is already 36 years old and is married to Gil, a farmer. They are blessed with two children who are both studying in the primary level: Gilina, 10 years old and Angelo, 6 years old. Analiza is hoping to give her children a full education. She doesn’t want them to experience the hardship of life she and her husband had been experiencing before because they were not able to gain a good education in college or even in high school.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Pili

texts.en:
Pili is a member of the Mtazamo borrower group in Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 22 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children,Her children are aged 5 and 3 years.

Pili started her own charcoal business3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Pili`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 20,000Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Pili hopes to save money,pay school fees,get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn and her husband, Tirso, help each other in maintaining their furniture-making business. They live in the mountainous place of Capellan, Ilagan, Isabela, where there is a lot of wood they can buy for their furniture-making business.

Jocelyn is already 39 years old and they have three children. Her eldest child is already 18 years old and is presently studying in college. Second, is Tirso B. Jr. - 12 years old who is currently studying in the primary level of education. The same with Kevin Kaye who is 8 years old.

Jocelyn is requesting a loan of PHP 9,000 from Kiva lenders as additional business capital for their furniture-making business. She is planning to buy woods like Molave, Narra, Acasia, Gemilina and other necessary materials used in their furniture-making.

Jocelyn knows that “patience makes the best business”. Thus, Jocelyn was really motivated to work harder and is teaching her children to be patient always in their poor living, telling them that someday they will be able to overcome the hardships of life. With the income from their business, Joceyn hopes that all her children will someday finish their college education.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Estela Marie

texts.en:
28-year old Estela and her husband live with her 77-year old mother and their three children whose ages range from five months to ten years old. As a homemaker, Estela's means to generate income are very limited and she is unable to augment her husband's income because she has no access to business capital. However, this month, Estela joined Kiva partner ASHI to request a loan to finance her husband's long time business of producing rice. Estela plans to eventually have a business buying and selling rice so that, aside from their own harvest, she can also help other farmers market their rice.

Estela realises how important a business could be to augment the family income. When financially stable through the profit her business makes, she plans to be able to send all of her children to college an opportunity she didn't have because of financial struggles.

loans.use: To begin a rice selling business

loans.name: Dakila

texts.en:
Dakila is 39-years old and a resident of Barangay Anguapan Tumauini, Isabela. She is married to Marcos who works as a farmer and a part-time construction worker. They have four children who are all studying. She hopes that they will be able to afford to send them to school until college.

Dakila sells vegetables and raw bananas in their village. She goes around the village to sell them. She started this business in order to help her husband provide for their children. She would like a loan of PHP 5,000 in order for her business to grow. She is hoping to become more productive in her business in order to attain her dream of providing an education for her children because, according to her, it is the only thing they can give them to assist them when they become independent.

loans.use: To obtain additional capital for vegetable selling business

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en: Esperanza owns and manages a general store located just in front of their residential house located in Sitio Anguapan, Tumauini, Isabela. From her business, she is generating an income of PHP250 each day, an amount being budgeted to their daily expenses. Esperanza would like to expand her business to be more profitable, thus could support their grandchildren who are already growing in numbers.  Esperanza is asking to obtain a loan amounting to PHP9, 000 to be used as her additional revolving capital for her business. She plans to purchase stocks of grocery items and hopefully her general store will also become more competent from other stores in their village. She hopes that her proposal will be approved and hopefully this will lead her in attaining her goals.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria says that she must persevere and maintain her street vending business in their village Calamagui 1st, Ilagan, Isabela. She dreams of giving all her children the education they need to have a better future. Gregoria is 56-years old with six children. She is married to Ernesto who is a tricycle driver.

Gregoria is patiently selling different snacks and children's toys in front of the elementary school in their village. She is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders of PHP 6,000.00 in order to provide additional capital for her vending business. She hopes the business will grow to become more profitable for her family needs. Gregoria and her husband work very hard for the welfare of her children.

loans.use: To provide additional capital

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia J. is from the village of Lao Sta. Cruz. She is 46 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Virginia owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2001, Virginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her 14th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: For business improvements

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: For porgress business

loans.name: Rishel

texts.en:
Rishel is a high school graduate who used to work as a housemaid after she graduated from high school. She just married a few months ago and is already pregnant. Her husband works as a farm laborer in their village. Hopefully, her business will uplift their living conditions to provide a nice future for their coming children. The couple lives in the village of Sitio Anguapan Tumauini, Isabela.

Rishel is engaged in selling rice and vegetables. She does it to help her husband in gaining income for the preparation of having a family. In her daily vending, she generates an income of 200 Philippine pesos (about $4) daily, which is somehow helpful in sustaining their daily needs. Rishel is now requesting a loan of PHP3,000 to be used as additional capital in purchasing vegetables and sacks of rice. She is praying that her business will be supported enough to maintain it and someday expand it.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is engaged in a general-store business in her village in the remote area of Cabisera 25, Ilagan, Isabela. She has been in the retailing business for two years. She started her business when her eldest child enrolled in college. She believes that her business could somehow support the educational needs of her children. She wants her business to progress in order to increase her income and sustain the needs of her family. 

Teresita wants to borrow PHP7,000 as additional business capital for her general store. She hopes that her loan will be granted because it will really be of great help in maintaining the growth of her business. Teresita is 45 years old and is married to Marcos, a farmer. They have four children and two of them are still studying.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Jovielyn

texts.en:
Jovielyn has run a variety store for almost 11 years. Managing her store is her way of helping her husband with supporting the needs of their family. Her income from her store is very helpful in sustaining the growing needs of her family. Thus, she wants to borrow a loan from Kiva lenders for PHP10,000 as additional capital. She wants her store to grow and become more profitable for her family.

Jovielyn is 36 years old and resides simply in the village of Capellan Ilagan, Isabela. She is happily married to Carlos, a furniture maker. They have four children, three of whom are already studying. Their youngest child is just 1 year old. Jovielyn is hoping to continue sending all her children to higher levels of education for them to obtain better jobs one day. Through their own perseverance and diligence in working, she believes that they will be able to attain what they dream.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Redento

texts.en:
“Time is gold” is the simple quotation shared by Redento S.. He is already 29 years old and operating a passenger tricycle in his village. He is earning at least PHP 250 daily from his business, which is used for daily basic needs. His wife, Armida, has been to Dubai to work in a factory so as to earn money for the family and save for their children’s education.

Redento is requesting a loan of PHP 4000 to maintain his passenger tricycle. Some of its parts have already been malfunctioning and need to be repaired. He is hoping that Kiva lenders will support him in his transport business.

loans.use: To repair his passenger tricycle

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia M. aims to give her family a progressive living with the support of her husband Juanito.  They are living in Almaguer South, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. Despite the hardships of life, the couple helps each other earn and save for the future of their children. 

Her hog raising business is being maintained well. Her ambition to further improve the business into a bigger one motivated Delia to sekk for financial assistance from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP10, 000 as additional working capital. Through her hog raising, Delia is able to help her husband financially in their farming which is their major source of income and also enable her to provide the educational needs of her children.  She hope that her business will grow and become successful with the continuous support of Kiva and by working hard.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Roa

texts.en:
Roa L. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag Bukidnon. She is sixty years old. Roa is part of a group running a sari-sari (variety) store in her community. Roa has been in business for over twenty years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. She also works occasionally as a dressmaker.

In 2009, Roa joined HSPFI to take advantage of its financial services. Roa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional goods so as to expand her business. This will be the first loan taken out by Roa from HSPFI.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that individual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nila

texts.en:
Nila M. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 46 years old, married and has two adult children. Nila owns and operates a business selling her ocean-caught fish to the local community. She has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2002, Nila joined PMPC to take advantage of its financial services. Nila successfully repaid her previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC, which she used to expand her business. Nila is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP that will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Nila from PMPC. Nila’s goal is to use additional profits to improve her family’s living conditions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that individual translations of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, including hooks & nets

loans.name: Gaudy's Group

texts.en: Gaudy is a 42 year old woman who is married with four children, ages 16 to 5 years old, and she cares for one orphan. She is a hard working and friendly lady with a retail shop as her business for three years in Kabatura Nyabubare County. Although there is a lot of competition, she is able to make 150,000/= as profits per week because of her good customer care approach. She is happy about her shop since it has provided for her family. In the future, Gaudy would like to turn her shop into a wholesale shop, as well as see all her children through school. She would like a loan to help increase the stock of goods in her shop ,so that she can make more profits.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods for increased profitability

loans.name: Damdinnavag

texts.en: Damdinnavag D. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and 2 sons in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband helps her with her food business while the oldest son attends a university and the  youngest son studies at high school. Damdinnavag`s past profession was as a teacher and she used to teach in the secondary school. In 2003, she went to Korea on a labor contract and came back to Mongolia in 2007. Damdinnavag  started her food trade business in 2007 and rents a wholesale pavilion at the Saruul, busy trade center in the sity. Today her business working capital amount is 8 million tugrugs /approx. 5525 USD/. She bought a new fence and building with business' profits and is now constructing a new house for his family.  Damdinnavag is a very open-minded, energetic and honest person. Her dream is to expand her business and for it to become more sustainable. She is requesting a 3 million tugrug /approx. 2072 USD/ loan to increase his working capital and procure more wholesale food products.

loans.use: to increase his working capital and procure more wholesale food products

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie is 35 years old. She is married to Dominador and they are blessed with three children. She has a hog raising business and this is her way of helping her husband in providing for the needs of their family. They are living in the small village at Sitio Anguapan, Tumauini, Isabela. Elvie hopes to continue sending all their three children to school until they finish college. 

She wants to borrow a loan of PHP 7,000.00. She will use the loan to purchase feed for the growth of her hogs.  She is also planning to venture into fresh meat vending. She used to sell pork meat in kilos in their village. Sometimes, Elvie sold the product on a cash basis but most of the time, her customers would pay after a week. She is hoping for her dreams to come true to be able to support also the needs of her three children who are currently studying hard, aiming to uplift their standard of living someday.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her hogs

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: For expanding their businesses

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa is already 60 years old. She is married to Wilfredo and they have seven children. Three were already married and four are still living with them.  Some of them are helping in the business while some are still studying.  The family resides peacefully in General Balao, Solana, Cagayan. 

Elisa wakes up early in the morning, keeping their house clean before she lives for work.  She sells dried fish and some vegetables around their village using her basket.  She wanted to avail a loan from the Kiva lenders amounting to PHP7, 000 as additional capital. The loan will enable her to buy more products. It will also enable her increase her vending income that will somehow satisfy her family needs.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou would like to request a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000. This amount is very helpful in maintaining the rice and corn thresher that farmers rent during harvest season. She is living in the small village of Anguapan, Tumauini, Isabela. 

Marilou also aspires to have a livestock business in order to have an additional source of income which, will be beneficial also for the sustenance of the agricultural business. Her plan with the loan includes purchasing piglets to fatten. Marilou is married to Wilfredo, the father of her five children. One of her five children is studying and she hopes to send her to college.

loans.use: To maintain farm equipment, and to purchase pigs
